comment_text.dn21:1.1.1: This late sutta exhibits considerable literary sophistication. The A-plot concerns Sakka’s rejection of his violent past and embrace of the Dhamma, while the B-plot concerns Pañcasikkha’s more modest growth from a libertine to a married man. This draws on such precedents as Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.2.4.4, where the centaur is urged to win his woman by seduction rather than force. | This discourse is quoted by name and a passage discussed at SN 22.4. In addition, the dialogue at MN 37 picks up directly where this leaves off and may be considered a sequel. A Sanskrit parallel published by Ernst Waldschmidt in 1979 is available on SuttaCentral as SF 241. A different discourse of the same name is found at SN 35.118.
comment_text.dn21:1.1.2: Rhys Davids follows the commentary in translating this “the cave of Indra’s Sāl Tree”. However the Sanskrit yāvacchailaguhāyām supports “hill cave”.
comment_text.dn21:1.2.1: Introduced in a minor role in DN 18, DN 19, and DN 20, Pañcasikha gets his moment to shine in this sutta. Outside of the Dīghanikāya, he appears only in SN 35.119. His name means “Fivecrest”, evidently in reference to his impressive hairdo; a nymph or group of nymphs bore the synonymous name Pañcacūḍā, “Five Topknots”. The centaur (gandhabba) was a wild rogue of music, dancing, and sex. He must be tamed, and here this is achieved through the power of love and filial respect. A less diplomatic approach is taken in Atharvaveda 4.37.7, where the gandharva with his “egg-crest” (śikhaṇḍino) is threatened with castration.
comment_text.dn21:1.2.4: The “arched harp” (vīṇa) was a stringed instrument held in the lap, whose form is clear from representations in ancient Indian sculptures in Bharhut, Amarāvatī, and Pawāyā, as well as the coins of Samudragupta. The strings, typically seven in number, were attached to the base of the soundbox and passed through holes in the parchment resonator to be tied with cords to the curved neck (these parts are listed at SN 35.246:4.17). It accompanied song or dance, and was played equally by men and women. It is not the modern Indian instrument called veena, which is a lute or stick zither, but rather is similar to the Burmese saung. | Gandhabbas are closely associated with music (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.2.4). Māra’s harp is described in the same way (SN 4.23:10.7), and tradition says they were in fact the same instrument.
comment_text.dn21:1.2.5: In the Buddhist hierarchy of divinity, gandhabbas occupy a more humble place than the gods of the thirty-three, yet here Pañcasikha appears with them in a position of honor. In DN 19:28.3 we saw that the even more exalted Brahmā takes the form of Pañcasikha. This fluidity is characteristic of old Vedic cosmology, where there is no clear hierarchy of divinity. The formalized hierarchies in Buddhism and Hinduism are a later conception.
comment_text.dn21:1.4.2: We will learn later of how Sakka’s appearance could be too disturbing for the Buddha while on retreat (DN 21:1.10.13). Pañcasikha, on the other hand, would appear alone, without a retinue. Note, however, that on subsequent occasions Sakka showed no such reticence, either because he was already a stream-enterer or because the Buddha was not in solitary retreat.
comment_text.dn21:1.4.8: The idea that the Buddha would be wooed by a love song seems like an absurd conceit, until you take into account the centaurs’ dangerous reputation as inveterate lechers. Pañcasikha wants to show that he is maturing and finally seeking a commitment in a respectable marriage.
comment_text.dn21:1.5.1: Suriyavaccasā (“Sunshine”) accords with the Vedic conception of the wife as the Sun (Sūryā, Rig Veda 10.85) who takes as husband Soma, the moon. She appears in Atharvaveda 8.10.27, which invokes the gandharvas with their female counterpart the “nymphs” (Pali accharā, Sanskrit apsaras).
comment_text.dn21:1.5.2: In Sanskrit literature, Timbaru (Sanskrit tumburu, “coriander”) was an elder gandharva musician in the courts of Indra and Kuvera. According to Rāmāyaṇa 3.4, he was cursed with a monstrous form by Kuvera due to an inappropriate lust for the nymph Rambhā. Upon his defeat at the hands of Rāma he was restored to his former status. Pañcasikha would have wanted to avoid a similar fate. Rather than Suriyavaccasā, the Sanskrit literature mentions his daughters Manuvantī and Sukeśī; the latter name (“fair-hair”) evokes the streaming rays of the sun   (Vāyupurāṇa 69.49 = Brahmāṇḍapurāṇa 2.7.13).
comment_text.dn21:1.5.7: Aṅgīrasi means “shining one” and is etymologically linked with agni (“fire”). Suriyavaccasā earned the name due to both her radiant nature and her family connections: her father Timbaru was a son of Kaśyapa, who was (according to certain lineages) brother of Aṅgīras, from whom the Aṅgīrasas were descended. In the Arthavaveda—the only early non-Buddhist source for a nymph named Suriyavaccasā—aṅgīrasi is associated with witchcraft (Atharvaveda 12.5.52). Aṅgīrasa is also a patronymic of the Buddha (DN 32:3.14).
comment_text.dn21:1.5.8: “Saints” is arahantā, which I normally translate as “perfected ones”.
comment_text.dn21:1.5.11: Parinibbāpaya, “please quench me”. Pañcasikha subverts imagery employed by the Buddha—quenching thirst, cooling breezes, extinguished flames—to erotic effect.
comment_text.dn21:1.5.17: Pañcasikha is showing off his literary skill. The same image, the elephant, illustrates opposing qualities, peaceful and violent. In these two sides of sensual desire, he reveals, unconsciously perhaps, the rapacious side of his own nature. For Pañcasikha, the elephant bursting its bonds illustrates his crazed devotion, whereas later it illustrates breaking free of desire (DN 21:1.12.45).
comment_text.dn21:1.5.36: For how a married couple may stay together in this life and the next, see AN 4.55.
comment_text.dn21:1.5.43: Pañcasikha is using the present participle jigīsāno in the historical present.
comment_text.dn21:1.5.49: A gandharva wedding is a pure love-match, without the blessing of parents or priests (Manu 3.32). Here, however, Pañcasikha wants to do the right thing and get the father’s blessing.
comment_text.dn21:1.6.2: If Pañcasikha was seeking the Buddha’s approval for his love-match, he was doomed to disappointment, as the Buddha and his mendicants do not involve themselves in arranging marriages. The Buddha sidesteps the issue by politely complementing Pañcasikha on his musicianship.
comment_text.dn21:1.6.4: “When did you compose” is also at MN 56:30.1.
comment_text.dn21:1.6.7: “Sister” (bhaginī) is a respectful term of address, but is normally used in a chaste sense. When Raṭṭhapāla calls his wives “sister”, they faint in shock (MN 82:23.4).
comment_text.dn21:1.6.8: Sikhaṇḍī (“egg-crested”) is the term for the centaur as seductive threat to women in Atharvaveda 4.37.7. It is also a poetic term for a peacock.
comment_text.dn21:1.9.3: It is rare for the Buddha to address a deity as “venerable” (āyasmā), a term usually reserved for monks. Moggallāna addresses Sakka as “the venerable Kosiya” at MN 37:10.6; Mahākassapa calls him Kosiya without honorific at Ud 3.7:3.12. | The word kosiya is explained by the commentaries as “owl”, which, if correct, would have been the totem for a clan of that name. It is, however, a patronymic: Rig Veda 1.10.11 has indra kauśika which means “Indra, son of Kuśika (or Kuśa)”. Kuśa grass is critical to the performance of Vedic rites, and the label probably initially implied “Brahmanized”, i.e. a king whose reign was authorized according to Vedic ritual. Kosiya is said to be a low class family name (Bu Pc 2:2.1.18).
comment_text.dn21:1.10.1: A paricārikā is a maid attending on a nymph (MN 37:8.12). | Bhūjati (variant bhuñjatī) does not seem to appear elsewhere.
comment_text.dn21:1.10.13: Sakka pointedly ignores this, but perhaps his shame at disturbing the Buddha’s meditation explains his oblique method of gaining an audience.
comment_text.dn21:1.11.5: This implies she was a stream-enterer.
comment_text.dn21:1.11.6: In Buddhism, sex is mutable between lives and even within one life (Bu Pj 1:10.6.1). Later Buddhists sometimes held that the status of a male was preferable. Here this is not stated outright, but the narrative implies that she thought her station was improved when becoming a male. Notably, it is not the Buddha who says this, but Sakka, relaying the story of another deity. That the proponent was a woman, at least formerly, is a trope of Indian literature: a woman is the ideal misogynist (see eg. Ja 61 or Śivapurāna chapter 4). Here, though, the situation is nuanced, because despite her (presumed) inferior status, she has better rebirth than the monks she served.
comment_text.dn21:1.11.10: The realm of centaurs is “inferior” because the centaurs are known for their ribald sexuality.
comment_text.dn21:1.11.13: Kutomukhā, which occurs only in this sutta, contrasts with sammukhā (“in the presence of”, “from the mouth of”). The commentary explains it as a rhetorical question, “Were you distracted or falling asleep?” Alternatively, it might mean “From whom did you learn the Buddha’s teaching?” It recurs later in the verses. This is not the only such case: duddiṭṭharūpaṁ and kāyaṁ brahmapurohitaṁ are other examples of terms found nowhere else in the Pali canon, yet found here both in prose and in verse. Clearly one has been copied from the other; it seems to me that the rarity of these terms and the greater coherence of the verses suggests that the prose is a (somewhat altered) summary of the verses.
comment_text.dn21:1.11.19: The commentary explains the verb “gained” (paṭilabhiṁsu) as serving dual roles here: “gaining” of “absorption mindfulness” (jhānasatiṁ), upon which they “gain” rebirth in the Brahmā realm. However, the verses below speak of “recollecting” (anussaraṁ) the Buddha’s teachings at this juncture. Compare Bu NP 23:1.1.20, where the king “remembered” his long-forgotten promise (vissaritvā cirena satiṁ paṭilabhitvā). AN 4.191:2.24 speaks of the “arising of memory” (satuppādo) in a deity when reminded of Dhamma passages they once recited as a monk. | The phrase kāyaṁ brahmapurohitaṁ is syntactically incongruous; I think it was clumsily copied from the verses below, where the required verb (ajjhagaṁsu) is present. The commentary explains it as “a Minister of Brahmā’s body” (brahmapurohitasarīraṁ), but in such contexts kāya usually means “host”.
comment_text.dn21:1.12.14: When bowing, it is a special sign of devotion to touch the feet of the one revered (eg. MN 89:9.1).
comment_text.dn21:1.12.19: Here Gopaka shifts from speaking about them in third person to speaking to them in second person.
comment_text.dn21:1.12.31: I.e. she was a lay person.
comment_text.dn21:1.12.35: Up until now, the verses have been spoken by Gopaka, but here a narrator appears.
comment_text.dn21:1.12.51: Normally rebirth is described as passing away in one realm then being reborn in another. Yet here the gods of the thirty-three—in their traditional abode on Mount Meru—were watching them literally fly from one realm to another.
comment_text.dn21:1.12.57: The truncated janind’ is not vocative janinda for Sakka, but nominative janindo for the Buddha.
comment_text.dn21:1.12.58: “Sakyan Sage” (sakyamuni) became a favorite epithet of the Buddha, but in early texts it appears only here and the Ratanasutta (Snp 2.1:4.2).
comment_text.dn21:1.12.65: The commentary says, “In this dispensation the explanation of the teaching is such that because of it, disciples become endowed with such qualities” (ettha sāsane evarūpā dhammappakāsanā, yāya sāvakā etehi guṇehi samannāgatā honti). This explains the feminine etādisī; pakasanā, which is normally neuter, is feminine here. This use is fairly common in later texts (it occurs at the conclusion of the Ṭīkā for this sutta).
comment_text.dn21:1.12.66: Kiṅkaṅkhati is a unique term for “doubt”.
comment_text.dn21:1.12.72: The end point of Gopaka’s speech is hard to determine, as there is no -ti to mark it. Various editions and translations either ignore the issue or end it in different places. The next line marks the beginning of Sakka’s direct speech to the Buddha, and I think it makes the best sense to assume that up to here he has been relating the story he was told.
comment_text.dn21:2.1.3: This question hints at Sakka’s own evolution from the battlegod of the Vedas to an acolyte of peace.
comment_text.dn21:2.1.6: Jealousy is wanting what others have, while stinginess is not wanting to share what you have.
comment_text.dn21:2.2.2: Compare with the side branch of dependent origination at DN 15:9.1, the origins of disputes at Snp 4.11, and the analysis of proliferation at MN 18. Note the constructive use of the “yes, and” method of questioning. Sakka finds wisdom due to his curiosity, neither being too-easily sated with a simple answer, nor quibbling that the answer is inadequate, but building on the foundations of understanding.
comment_text.dn21:2.2.17: Here we depart from the normal sequence, which is that feelings give rise to craving (taṇhā). In Snp 4.11:6.1 it is said that pleasure and pain give rise to desire, not thought.
comment_text.dn21:2.2.23: “Judgments that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions” renders papañcasaññāsaṅkhā. Again the sequence departs from MN 18:16.1, which says that thoughts—which are normal and morally neutral psychological processes—give rise to “proliferation” (papañca), which is when craving and delusion cause thought to spin out of control. “Proliferation” then solidifies into “judgments” that fuel an individual’s delusion of “self” persisting through time.
comment_text.dn21:2.3.14: That is, second jhāna is better than first jhāna.
comment_text.dn21:2.3.21: Overwhelmingly, the suttas speak of happiness in the path to liberation. They do, however, also acknowledge that sometimes temporary states of sadness leading to disillusionment can spur a person on the path.
comment_text.dn21:2.3.22: It is hard to know what the text is getting at here, as there is no “sadness” in any jhāna.
comment_text.dn21:2.4.3: Here the Buddha emphasizes the psychological and spiritual underpinnings of the “monastic code” (pātimokkha).
comment_text.dn21:2.4.26: The suttas frequently describe three kinds of search: for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path (eg. SN 45.161:7.3). The last search led the Buddha to awakening (MN 26:15.1).
comment_text.dn21:2.5.16: Sakka switches his term of address for the Buddha from mārisa to the more respectful bhante here, then back to mārisa below. This passage is found at MN 114:24.5, where bhante is used, suggesting it was imported from there.
comment_text.dn21:2.5.17: For a more detailed analysis of this, see MN 152.
comment_text.dn21:2.6.2: The Pali ekanta (“single”) here is a little tricky; it could mean either “the same” or “of one goal”. The Sanskrit has just eka (ekakāmā ekacchandāḥ, “one desire, one wish”), while the commentary explains the first and last terms as “one goal” and the middle terms as “one”.
comment_text.dn21:2.6.6: The Buddha points out that spiritual teachers, when faced with a world of experiential diversity, tend to prioritize their own experience or doctrine, dismissing others as less real or meaningful.
comment_text.dn21:2.6.9: Yogakkhema (“sanctuary from the yoke”) is a metaphor for Nibbana that draws from the literal sense of khema as an oasis or sanctuary for men and beasts. After a hard day’s journey, a caravan would stop to rest, “unyoke” the draft animals, lay down the burden, and refresh themselves in the cool waters.
comment_text.dn21:2.6.12: This passage is quoted by name by Hāliddikāni at SN 22.4:1.4. The topic is picked up again in MN 31, where we see the extent to which Sakka has learned his lesson. | The text has “mendicants” here, but “ascetics and brahmins” immediately before and after. The quotation at SN 22.4:1.4 has “ascetics and brahmins”, so it is likely the text here is in error.
comment_text.dn21:2.6.17: This is the final substantive question of the series. It is picked up in MN 37:2.2 where Sakka, in a subsequent visit, inquires further as to the nature of those who have realized the ultimate goal.
comment_text.dn21:2.7.1: “Turbulence” is ejā, from a root meaning “motion, agitation”, and hence the opposite of the “imperturbable” (aneja) peace of the Buddha (SN 35.90).
comment_text.dn21:2.7.28: “Nectar” is ojā, in Vedic texts called soma or amṛta (“ambrosia” of immortality). The battle over nectar by gods (deva) and demons (asura) is a very ancient element of Indo-European mythology.
comment_text.dn21:2.7.30: Here Sakka makes a clean break from the violent delights he enjoyed in former (Vedic) times.
comment_text.dn21:2.8.5: Punarāyu is a unique term. It probably means that Sakka can extend his current fortunate birth due to the merit of Dhamma.
comment_text.dn21:2.8.10: To die “unconfused” or “consciously” is said to be a benefit of Dhamma practice (eg. AN 5.215:2.3).
comment_text.dn21:2.8.15: “According to method” (ñāyena) recalls ñāyapaṭipanno as a description of the noble ones. It means practicing according with the noble eightfold path, a “method” that yields definite results.
comment_text.dn21:2.8.21: This refers to the possibility of achieving perfection (arahattā).
comment_text.dn21:2.8.26: That is, after passing away as Sakka and being reborn as a human, he will subsequently return to the heaven realm.
comment_text.dn21:2.8.30: He predicts that his final life will be in this high realm that is inhabited by non-returners (AN 9.12:6.7).
comment_text.dn21:2.9.29: Karomasi is middle imperative 1st plural, “we should do”, glossed by the commentary as “we should pay homage” (namakkāraṁ karoma).
comment_text.dn21:2.9.30: Samaṁ is an indeclinable in the sense “likewise”.
comment_text.dn21:2.9.32: Sāmaṁ is an indeclinable in the sense “oneself, personally, one’s own”.
comment_text.dn21:2.10.4: A gandharva wedding must be a mutual love match.
comment_text.dn21:2.10.5: “Touching the ground with his hand” is a unique gesture in the early Pali, immortalized in later legend when the Buddha touches the ground to invoke the Earth Goddess as witness of his striving.
comment_text.dn21:2.10.11: Sakka is also said to have been accompanied by 80,000 deities at SN 40.10:4.4. This is one of many indications that this is a late discourse, several of which have been touched on above: late or unique terminology; fancy literary styles; adoption of doctrinal passages from elsewhere in a sometimes clumsy fashion; and so on. In determining whether a sutta is late or early, we do not rely on a single definitive reason, but on a cluster of independent criteria which taken together are most easily explained in terms of historical development.

root_text.dn21:1.1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā magadhesu viharati, pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.1.3: Tena kho pana samayena sakkassa devānamindassa ussukkaṁ udapādi bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
root_text.dn21:1.1.5: “kahaṁ nu kho bhagavā etarahi viharati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho”ti?
root_text.dn21:1.1.6: Addasā kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṁ magadhesu viharantaṁ pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.1.8: “ayaṁ, mārisā, bhagavā magadhesu viharati, pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.1.9: Yadi pana, mārisā, mayaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyāma arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhan”ti?
root_text.dn21:1.1.10: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho devā tāvatiṁsā sakkassa devānamindassa paccassosuṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.2.1: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṁ gandhabbadevaputtaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn21:1.2.2: “ayaṁ, tāta pañcasikha, bhagavā magadhesu viharati pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.2.3: Yadi pana, tāta pañcasikha, mayaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyāma arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhan”ti?
root_text.dn21:1.2.4: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya sakkassa devānamindassa anucariyaṁ upāgami.
root_text.dn21:1.2.5: Atha kho sakko devānamindo devehi tāvatiṁsehi parivuto pañcasikhena gandhabbadevaputtena purakkhato—
root_text.dn21:1.2.6: seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva—devesu tāvatiṁsesu antarahito magadhesu pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate paccuṭṭhāsi.
root_text.dn21:1.3.1: Tena kho pana samayena vediyako pabbato atiriva obhāsajāto hoti ambasaṇḍā ca brāhmaṇagāmo yathā taṁ devānaṁ devānubhāvena.
root_text.dn21:1.3.3: “ādittassu nāmajja vediyako pabbato jhāyatisu nāmajja vediyako pabbato jalatisu. Nāmajja vediyako pabbato.
root_text.dn21:1.3.4: Kiṁsu nāmajja vediyako pabbato atiriva obhāsajāto ambasaṇḍā ca brāhmaṇagāmo”ti;
root_text.dn21:1.4.1: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṁ gandhabbadevaputtaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn21:1.4.2: “durupasaṅkamā kho, tāta pañcasikha, tathāgatā mādisena, jhāyī jhānaratā, tadantaraṁ paṭisallīnā.
root_text.dn21:1.4.3: Yadi pana tvaṁ, tāta pañcasikha, bhagavantaṁ paṭhamaṁ pasādeyyāsi, tayā, tāta, paṭhamaṁ pasāditaṁ pacchā mayaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyāma arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhan”ti.
root_text.dn21:1.4.4: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya yena indasālaguhā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā:
root_text.dn21:1.4.5: “ettāvatā me bhagavā neva atidūre bhavissati nāccāsanne, saddañca me sossatī”ti—
root_text.dn21:1.4.8: Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ assāvesi, imā ca gāthā abhāsi buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṅghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā:
root_text.dn21:1.6.1: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā pañcasikhaṁ gandhabbadevaputtaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn21:1.6.2: “saṁsandati kho te, pañcasikha, tantissaro gītassarena, gītassaro ca tantissarena;
root_text.dn21:1.6.3: na ca pana te, pañcasikha, tantissaro gītassaraṁ ativattati, gītassaro ca tantissaraṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.6.4: Kadā saṁyūḷhā pana te, pañcasikha, imā gāthā buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṅghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā”ti?
root_text.dn21:1.6.5: “Ekamidaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ bhagavā uruvelāyaṁ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe paṭhamābhisambuddho.
root_text.dn21:1.6.6: Tena kho panāhaṁ, bhante, samayena bhaddā nāma sūriyavacchasā timbaruno gandhabbarañño dhītā, tamabhikaṅkhāmi.
root_text.dn21:1.6.7: Sā kho pana, bhante, bhaginī parakāminī hoti;
root_text.dn21:1.6.8: sikhaṇḍī nāma mātalissa saṅgāhakassa putto, tamabhikaṅkhati.
root_text.dn21:1.6.9: Yato kho ahaṁ, bhante, taṁ bhaginiṁ nālatthaṁ kenaci pariyāyena.
root_text.dn21:1.6.10: Athāhaṁ beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya yena timbaruno gandhabbarañño nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ assāvesiṁ, imā ca gāthā abhāsiṁ buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṅghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā—
root_text.dn21:1.7.10: Evaṁ vutte, bhante, bhaddā sūriyavacchasā maṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn21:1.7.11: ‘na kho me, mārisa, so bhagavā sammukhā diṭṭho, api ca sutoyeva me so bhagavā devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sudhammāyaṁ sabhāyaṁ upanaccantiyā.
root_text.dn21:1.7.12: Yato kho tvaṁ, mārisa, taṁ bhagavantaṁ kittesi, hotu no ajja samāgamo’ti.
root_text.dn21:1.7.13: Soyeva no, bhante, tassā bhaginiyā saddhiṁ samāgamo ahosi.
root_text.dn21:1.8.2: “paṭisammodati pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto bhagavatā, bhagavā ca pañcasikhenā”ti.
root_text.dn21:1.8.3: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṁ gandhabbadevaputtaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn21:1.8.5: ‘sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’”ti.
root_text.dn21:1.8.6: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādeti:
root_text.dn21:1.8.7: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”ti.
root_text.dn21:1.8.8: “Evaṁ sukhī hotu, pañcasikha, sakko devānamindo sāmacco saparijano;
root_text.dn21:1.8.9: sukhakāmā hi devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā ye caññe santi puthukāyā”ti.
root_text.dn21:1.8.10: Evañca pana tathāgatā evarūpe mahesakkhe yakkhe abhivadanti.
root_text.dn21:1.8.11: Abhivadito sakko devānamindo bhagavato indasālaguhaṁ pavisitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
root_text.dn21:1.8.12: Devāpi tāvatiṁsā indasālaguhaṁ pavisitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu.
root_text.dn21:1.8.13: Pañcasikhopi gandhabbadevaputto indasālaguhaṁ pavisitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
root_text.dn21:1.9.1: Tena kho pana samayena indasālaguhā visamā santī samā samapādi, sambādhā santī urundā samapādi, andhakāro guhāyaṁ antaradhāyi, āloko udapādi yathā taṁ devānaṁ devānubhāvena.
root_text.dn21:1.9.2: Atha kho bhagavā sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn21:1.9.3: “acchariyamidaṁ āyasmato kosiyassa, abbhutamidaṁ āyasmato kosiyassa tāva bahukiccassa bahukaraṇīyassa yadidaṁ idhāgamanan”ti.
root_text.dn21:1.9.4: “Cirapaṭikāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamitukāmo; api ca devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ kehici kehici kiccakaraṇīyehi byāvaṭo; evāhaṁ nāsakkhiṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.9.5: Ekamidaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati salaḷāgārake.
root_text.dn21:1.9.6: Atha khvāhaṁ, bhante, sāvatthiṁ agamāsiṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
root_text.dn21:1.10.1: Tena kho pana, bhante, samayena bhagavā aññatarena samādhinā nisinno hoti, bhūjati ca nāma vessavaṇassa mahārājassa paricārikā bhagavantaṁ paccupaṭṭhitā hoti, pañjalikā namassamānā tiṭṭhati.
root_text.dn21:1.10.4: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”’ti.
root_text.dn21:1.10.5: Evaṁ vutte, bhante, sā bhūjati maṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn21:1.10.8: ‘Tena hi, bhagini, yadā bhagavā tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito hoti, atha mama vacanena bhagavantaṁ abhivādehi:
root_text.dn21:1.10.9: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”’ti.
root_text.dn21:1.10.10: Kacci me sā, bhante, bhaginī bhagavantaṁ abhivādesi?
root_text.dn21:1.10.12: “Abhivādesi maṁ sā, devānaminda, bhaginī, sarāmahaṁ tassā bhaginiyā vacanaṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.10.13: Api cāhaṁ āyasmato nemisaddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito”ti.
root_text.dn21:1.11.1: “Ye te, bhante, devā amhehi paṭhamataraṁ tāvatiṁsakāyaṁ upapannā, tesaṁ me sammukhā sutaṁ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ:
root_text.dn21:1.11.2: ‘yadā tathāgatā loke uppajjanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā, dibbā kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā’ti.
root_text.dn21:1.11.3: Taṁ me idaṁ, bhante, sakkhidiṭṭhaṁ yato tathāgato loke uppanno arahaṁ sammāsambuddho, dibbā kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyāti.
root_text.dn21:1.11.5: Idheva, bhante, kapilavatthusmiṁ gopikā nāma sakyadhītā ahosi buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṅghe pasannā sīlesu paripūrakārinī.
root_text.dn21:1.11.6: Sā itthittaṁ virājetvā purisattaṁ bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā.
root_text.dn21:1.11.7: Devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ amhākaṁ puttattaṁ ajjhupagatā.
root_text.dn21:1.11.10: Aññepi, bhante, tayo bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ caritvā hīnaṁ gandhabbakāyaṁ upapannā.
root_text.dn21:1.11.11: Te pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārayamānā amhākaṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgacchanti amhākaṁ pāricariyaṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.11.12: Te amhākaṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgate amhākaṁ pāricariyaṁ gopako devaputto paṭicodesi:
root_text.dn21:1.11.13: ‘kutomukhā nāma tumhe, mārisā, tassa bhagavato dhammaṁ assuttha—
root_text.dn21:1.11.14: ahañhi nāma itthikā samānā buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṅghe pasannā sīlesu paripūrakārinī itthittaṁ virājetvā purisattaṁ bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā, devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ sakkassa devānamindassa puttattaṁ ajjhupagatā.
root_text.dn21:1.11.17: Tumhe pana, mārisā, bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ caritvā hīnaṁ gandhabbakāyaṁ upapannā.
root_text.dn21:1.11.18: Duddiṭṭharūpaṁ vata bho addasāma, ye mayaṁ addasāma sahadhammike hīnaṁ gandhabbakāyaṁ upapanne’ti.
root_text.dn21:1.11.19: Tesaṁ, bhante, gopakena devaputtena paṭicoditānaṁ dve devā diṭṭheva dhamme satiṁ paṭilabhiṁsu kāyaṁ brahmapurohitaṁ, eko pana devo kāme ajjhāvasi.
root_text.dn21:1.13.2: “dīgharattaṁ visuddho kho ayaṁ yakkho, yaṁ kiñci maṁ pañhaṁ pucchissati, sabbaṁ taṁ atthasañhitaṁyeva pucchissati, no anatthasañhitaṁ.
root_text.dn21:1.13.3: Yañcassāhaṁ puṭṭho byākarissāmi, taṁ khippameva ājānissatī”ti.
root_text.dn21:1.13.4: Atha kho bhagavā sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
root_text.dn21:2.1.1: Katāvakāso sakko devānamindo bhagavatā imaṁ bhagavantaṁ paṭhamaṁ pañhaṁ apucchi:
root_text.dn21:2.1.2: “Kiṁsaṁyojanā nu kho, mārisa, devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā ye caññe santi puthukāyā, te:
root_text.dn21:2.1.3: ‘averā adaṇḍā asapattā abyāpajjā viharemu averino’ti iti ca nesaṁ hoti, atha ca pana saverā sadaṇḍā sasapattā sabyāpajjā viharanti saverino”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.1.4: Itthaṁ sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṁ pañhaṁ apucchi.
root_text.dn21:2.1.6: “Issāmacchariyasaṁyojanā kho, devānaminda, devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā ye caññe santi puthukāyā, te:
root_text.dn21:2.1.7: ‘averā adaṇḍā asapattā abyāpajjā viharemu averino’ti iti ca nesaṁ hoti, atha ca pana saverā sadaṇḍā sasapattā sabyāpajjā viharanti saverino”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.1.8: Itthaṁ bhagavā sakkassa devānamindassa pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākāsi.
root_text.dn21:2.1.9: Attamano sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandi anumodi:
root_text.dn21:2.1.11: Tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhā vigatā kathaṅkathā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.2.1: Itiha sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ uttari pañhaṁ apucchi:
root_text.dn21:2.2.2: “Issāmacchariyaṁ pana, mārisa, kiṁnidānaṁ kiṁsamudayaṁ kiṁjātikaṁ kiṁpabhavaṁ;
root_text.dn21:2.2.5: “Issāmacchariyaṁ kho, devānaminda, piyāppiyanidānaṁ piyāppiyasamudayaṁ piyāppiyajātikaṁ piyāppiyapabhavaṁ;
root_text.dn21:2.2.8: “Piyāppiyaṁ pana, mārisa, kiṁnidānaṁ kiṁsamudayaṁ kiṁjātikaṁ kiṁpabhavaṁ;
root_text.dn21:2.2.11: “Piyāppiyaṁ kho, devānaminda, chandanidānaṁ chandasamudayaṁ chandajātikaṁ chandapabhavaṁ;
root_text.dn21:2.2.14: “Chando pana, mārisa, kiṁnidāno kiṁsamudayo kiṁjātiko kiṁpabhavo;
root_text.dn21:2.2.17: “Chando kho, devānaminda, vitakkanidāno vitakkasamudayo vitakkajātiko vitakkapabhavo;
root_text.dn21:2.2.20: “Vitakko pana, mārisa, kiṁnidāno kiṁsamudayo kiṁjātiko kiṁpabhavo;
root_text.dn21:2.2.23: “Vitakko kho, devānaminda, papañcasaññāsaṅkhānidāno papañcasaññāsaṅkhāsamudayo papañcasaññāsaṅkhājātiko papañcasaññāsaṅkhāpabhavo;
root_text.dn21:2.3.1: “Kathaṁ paṭipanno pana, mārisa, bhikkhu papañcasaññāsaṅkhānirodhasāruppagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ paṭipanno hotī”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.3.9: Somanassampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
root_text.dn21:2.3.11: ‘imaṁ kho me somanassaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpaṁ somanassaṁ na sevitabbaṁ.
root_text.dn21:2.3.13: ‘imaṁ kho me somanassaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpaṁ somanassaṁ sevitabbaṁ.
root_text.dn21:2.3.14: Tattha yañce savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ, yañce avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ, ye avitakke avicāre, te paṇītatare.
root_text.dn21:2.3.15: Somanassampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti.

root_text.dn21:2.6.3: “Na kho, devānaminda, sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekantavādā ekantasīlā ekantachandā ekantaajjhosānā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.6.4: “Kasmā pana, mārisa, na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekantavādā ekantasīlā ekantachandā ekantaajjhosānā”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.6.6: Tasmiṁ anekadhātunānādhātusmiṁ loke yaṁ yadeva sattā dhātuṁ abhinivisanti, taṁ tadeva thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharanti:
root_text.dn21:2.6.8: Tasmā na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekantavādā ekantasīlā ekantachandā ekantaajjhosānā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.6.9: “Sabbeva nu kho, mārisa, samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.6.10: “Na kho, devānaminda, sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.6.11: “Kasmā pana, mārisa, na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.6.12: “Ye kho, devānaminda, bhikkhū taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttā te accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā.
root_text.dn21:2.6.13: Tasmā na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.6.14: Itthaṁ bhagavā sakkassa devānamindassa pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākāsi.
root_text.dn21:2.6.15: Attamano sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandi anumodi:
root_text.dn21:2.6.17: Tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhā vigatā kathaṅkathā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.6.18: Itiha sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn21:2.7.1: “Ejā, bhante, rogo, ejā gaṇḍo, ejā sallaṁ, ejā imaṁ purisaṁ parikaḍḍhati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
root_text.dn21:2.7.3: Yesāhaṁ, bhante, pañhānaṁ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu okāsakammampi nālatthaṁ, te me bhagavatā byākatā.
root_text.dn21:2.7.4: Dīgharattānusayitañca pana me vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ, tañca bhagavatā abbuḷhan”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.7.5: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, devānaminda, ime pañhe aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.7.6: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, bhante, ime pañhe aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.7.7: “Yathā kathaṁ pana te, devānaminda, byākaṁsu? Sace te agaru bhāsassū”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.7.8: “Na kho me, bhante, garu yatthassa bhagavā nisinno bhagavantarūpo vā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.7.10: “Yesvāhaṁ, bhante, maññāmi samaṇabrāhmaṇā āraññikā pantasenāsanāti, tyāhaṁ upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe pucchāmi, te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaṁyeva paṭipucchanti:
root_text.dn21:2.7.15: ‘kiṁ panāyasmā, devānaminda, kammaṁ katvā imaṁ ṭhānaṁ patto’ti?
root_text.dn21:2.7.18: ‘sakko ca no devānamindo diṭṭho, yañca no apucchimhā, tañca no byākāsī’ti.
root_text.dn21:2.7.19: Te aññadatthu mamaṁyeva sāvakā sampajjanti, na cāhaṁ tesaṁ.
root_text.dn21:2.7.20: Ahaṁ kho pana, bhante, bhagavato sāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.7.22: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, devānaminda, ito pubbe evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.7.23: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, bhante, ito pubbe evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.7.24: “Yathā kathaṁ pana tvaṁ, devānaminda, abhijānāsi ito pubbe evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.7.26: Tasmiṁ kho pana, bhante, saṅgāme devā jiniṁsu, asurā parājayiṁsu.
root_text.dn21:2.7.27: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmassa etadahosi:
root_text.dn21:2.7.28: ‘yā ceva dāni dibbā ojā yā ca asurā ojā, ubhayametaṁ devā paribhuñjissantī’ti.
root_text.dn21:2.7.29: So kho pana me, bhante, vedapaṭilābho somanassapaṭilābho sadaṇḍāvacaro sasatthāvacaro na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati.
root_text.dn21:2.7.30: Yo kho pana me ayaṁ, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṁ sutvā vedapaṭilābho somanassapaṭilābho, so adaṇḍāvacaro asatthāvacaro ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattatī”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.8.1: “Kiṁ pana tvaṁ, devānaminda, atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedesī”ti?
root_text.dn21:2.8.2: “Cha kho ahaṁ, bhante, atthavase sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
root_text.dn21:2.8.7: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, paṭhamaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
root_text.dn21:2.8.12: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, dutiyaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
root_text.dn21:2.8.17: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, tatiyaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
root_text.dn21:2.8.22: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, catutthaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
root_text.dn21:2.8.27: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, pañcamaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
root_text.dn21:2.8.32: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, chaṭṭhaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
root_text.dn21:2.8.33: Ime kho ahaṁ, bhante, cha atthavase sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
root_text.dn21:2.10.1: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṁ gandhabbaputtaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn21:2.10.2: “bahūpakāro kho mesi tvaṁ, tāta pañcasikha, yaṁ tvaṁ bhagavantaṁ paṭhamaṁ pasādesi.
root_text.dn21:2.10.3: Tayā, tāta, paṭhamaṁ pasāditaṁ pacchā mayaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamimhā arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ.
root_text.dn21:2.10.4: Pettike vā ṭhāne ṭhapayissāmi, gandhabbarājā bhavissasi, bhaddañca te sūriyavacchasaṁ dammi, sā hi te abhipatthitā”ti.
root_text.dn21:2.10.5: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pāṇinā pathaviṁ parāmasitvā tikkhattuṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
root_text.dn21:2.10.9: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṁ bhaññamāne sakkassa devānamindassa virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi:
root_text.dn21:2.10.12: iti ye sakkena devānamindena ajjhiṭṭhapañhā puṭṭhā, te bhagavatā byākatā.

translation_text.dn21:1.1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans, where east of Rājagaha there is a brahmin village named Ambasaṇḍā, north of which, on Mount Vediyaka, is Indra’s hill cave.
translation_text.dn21:1.1.3: Now at that time Sakka, the lord of gods, grew eager to see the Buddha.
translation_text.dn21:1.1.5: “Where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
translation_text.dn21:1.1.6: Seeing that the Buddha was at Indra’s hill cave,
translation_text.dn21:1.1.7: he addressed the gods of the thirty-three,
translation_text.dn21:1.1.8: “Good fellows, the Buddha is staying in the land of the Magadhans at Indra’s hill cave.
translation_text.dn21:1.1.9: What if we were to go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
translation_text.dn21:1.2.1: Then Sakka addressed the centaur Pañcasikha,
translation_text.dn21:1.2.2: “Dear Pañcasikha, the Buddha is staying in the land of the Magadhans at Indra’s hill cave.
translation_text.dn21:1.2.3: What if we were to go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
translation_text.dn21:1.2.4: “Yes, lord,” replied the centaur Pañcasikha. Taking his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, he went as Sakka’s attendant.
translation_text.dn21:1.2.5: Then Sakka went at the head of a retinue consisting of the gods of the thirty-three and the godling centaur Pañcasikha.
translation_text.dn21:1.2.6: As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the heaven of the gods of the thirty-three and landed on Mount Vediyaka north of Ambasaṇḍā.
translation_text.dn21:1.3.1: Now at that time a dazzling light appeared over Mount Vediyaka and Ambasaṇḍā, as happens through the glory of the gods.
translation_text.dn21:1.3.2: People in the villages round about, terrified, shocked, and awestruck, said,
translation_text.dn21:1.3.3: “Mount Vediyaka must be on fire today, blazing and burning!
translation_text.dn21:1.3.4: Oh why has such a dazzling light appeared over Mount Vediyaka and Ambasaṇḍā?”
translation_text.dn21:1.4.1: Then Sakka addressed the centaur Pañcasikha,
translation_text.dn21:1.4.2: “My dear Pañcasikha, it is hard for one like me to get near the Realized Ones while they are on retreat practicing absorption, enjoying absorption.
translation_text.dn21:1.4.3: But if you were to charm the Buddha first, then I could go to see him.”
translation_text.dn21:1.4.4: “Yes, lord,” replied the centaur Pañcasikha. Taking his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, he went to Indra’s hill cave. When he had drawn near, he stood to one side, thinking,
translation_text.dn21:1.4.5: “This is neither too far nor too near; and he’ll hear my voice.”
translation_text.dn21:1.4.8: Standing to one side, Pañcasikha played his arched harp, and sang these verses on the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the perfected ones, and sensual love.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.2: I pay homage to your father Timbaru,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.3: through whom was born a lady so fine,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.4: to fill me with a joy I never knew.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.5: As sweet as a breeze to one who’s sweating,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.6: or when thirsty, a sweet and cooling drink,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.7: so dear are you, Aṅgīrasi, to me—
translation_text.dn21:1.5.8: just like the teaching is to all the saints!
translation_text.dn21:1.5.9: Like a cure when you’re struck by fever dire,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.10: or food to ease the hunger pain,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.11: come on, Bhaddā, please put out my fire,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.12: quench me like water on a flame.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.13: As elephants burning in the heat of summer,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.14: sink down in a lotus pond to rest,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.15: so cool, full of petals and of pollen—
translation_text.dn21:1.5.16: that’s how I would plunge into your breast.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.17: Like elephants bursting bonds in rutting season,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.18: beating off the pricks of lance and pikes—
translation_text.dn21:1.5.19: I just don’t understand what is the reason
translation_text.dn21:1.5.20: I’m so crazy for your shapely thighs!
translation_text.dn21:1.5.21: For you, my heart is full of passion,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.22: I’m in a besotted state of mind.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.23: There is no going back, I’m just not able,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.24: I’m like a fish that’s hooked up on the line.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.25: Come on, my Bhaddā, hold me, fair of thighs!
translation_text.dn21:1.5.26: Embrace me, maid of captivating eyes!
translation_text.dn21:1.5.27: Take me in your arms, my lovely lady,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.28: that’s all I’d ever want or could desire.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.29: Ah, then my desire was such a small thing,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.30: my sweet, with your curling wavy hair;
translation_text.dn21:1.5.31: now, like to arahants an offering,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.32: it’s grown so very much from there.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.33: Whatever the merit I have forged
translation_text.dn21:1.5.34: by giving to such perfected beings—
translation_text.dn21:1.5.37: Whatever the merit I have forged
translation_text.dn21:1.5.41: As the Sakyan, absorbed, did meditate
translation_text.dn21:1.5.42: at one, alert, and mindful too,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.43: the sage seeking the state free of death—
translation_text.dn21:1.5.44: so I, oh my Sunshine, seek for you!
translation_text.dn21:1.5.45: And just like the sage would delight,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.46: once he had awakened to the truth,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.47: so I would delight, my fine lady,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.48: were I to become one with you.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.49: If Sakka were to grant me one wish,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.50: as Lord of the Thirty and Three,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.51: my Bhaddā, you’re all I would wish for,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.52: so strong is the love in me.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.53: Like a freshly blossoming sal tree
translation_text.dn21:1.5.54: is your father, my lady so wise.
translation_text.dn21:1.5.55: I pay homage to he, bowing humbly,
translation_text.dn21:1.5.56: whose daughter is of such a kind.”
translation_text.dn21:1.6.1: When Pañcasikha had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
translation_text.dn21:1.6.2: “Pañcasikha, the sound of your strings blends well with the sound of your singing,
translation_text.dn21:1.6.3: so that neither overpowers the other.
translation_text.dn21:1.6.4: But when did you compose these verses on the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the perfected ones, and sensual love?”
translation_text.dn21:1.6.5: “This one time, sir, when you were first awakened, you were staying in Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
translation_text.dn21:1.6.6: And at that time I was in love with Bhaddā Suriyavaccasā, who they call ‘Darling Sunshine’, the daughter of the centaur king Timbaru.
translation_text.dn21:1.6.8: It was the one named Sikhaṇḍī, the son of Mātali the chariot handler, who she loved.
translation_text.dn21:1.6.9: Since I couldn’t win that sister by any means,
translation_text.dn21:1.6.10: I took my arched harp to Timbaru’s home, where I played those verses.
translation_text.dn21:1.7.10: When I finished, Suriyavaccasā said to me,
translation_text.dn21:1.7.11: ‘Good fellow, I have not personally seen the Buddha. But I did hear about him when I went to dance for the gods of the thirty-three in the Hall of Clear Right.
translation_text.dn21:1.7.12: Since you extol the Buddha, let us meet up today.’
translation_text.dn21:1.7.13: And that’s when I met up with that sister.
translation_text.dn21:1.7.14: But we have not met since.”
translation_text.dn21:1.8.1: Then Sakka, lord of gods, thought,
translation_text.dn21:1.8.2: “Pañcasikha is exchanging pleasantries with the Buddha.”
translation_text.dn21:1.8.4: “My dear Pañcasikha, please bow to the Buddha for me, saying:
translation_text.dn21:1.8.5: ‘Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.’”
translation_text.dn21:1.8.6: “Yes, lord,” replied Pañcasikha. He bowed to the Buddha and said,
translation_text.dn21:1.8.7: “Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.”
translation_text.dn21:1.8.8: “So may Sakka with his ministers and retinue be happy, Pañcasikha,” said the Buddha,
translation_text.dn21:1.8.9: “for all want to be happy—whether gods, humans, titans, dragons, centaurs, or any of the other diverse creatures there may be.”
translation_text.dn21:1.8.10: For that is how the Realized Ones salute such illustrious spirits.
translation_text.dn21:1.8.11: And being saluted by the Buddha, Sakka entered Indra’s hill cave, bowed to the Buddha, and stood to one side.
translation_text.dn21:1.8.12: And the gods of the thirty-three did likewise,
translation_text.dn21:1.9.1: And at that time the uneven places were evened out, the cramped places were opened up, the darkness vanished in the cave and light appeared, as happens through the glory of the gods.
translation_text.dn21:1.9.2: Then the Buddha said to Sakka,
translation_text.dn21:1.9.3: “It’s incredible and amazing that you, the venerable Kosiya, who has so many duties and so much to do, should come here.”
translation_text.dn21:1.9.4: “For a long time I’ve wanted to come and see the Buddha, but I wasn’t able, being prevented by my many duties and responsibilities for the gods of the thirty-three.
translation_text.dn21:1.9.5: This one time, sir, the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the frankincense-tree hut.
translation_text.dn21:1.9.6: Then I went to Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
translation_text.dn21:1.10.1: But at that time the Buddha was sitting immersed in some kind of meditation. And a divine maiden of Great King Vessavaṇa named Bhūjati was attending on the Buddha, standing there paying homage to him with joined palms.
translation_text.dn21:1.10.3: ‘Sister, please bow to the Buddha for me, saying:
translation_text.dn21:1.10.4: “Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.”’
translation_text.dn21:1.10.5: When I said this, she said to me,
translation_text.dn21:1.10.6: ‘It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,
translation_text.dn21:1.10.8: ‘Well then, sister, please convey my message when the Buddha emerges from that immersion.’
translation_text.dn21:1.10.10: I hope that sister bowed to you?
translation_text.dn21:1.10.11: Do you remember what she said?”
translation_text.dn21:1.10.12: “She did bow, lord of gods, and I remember what she said.
translation_text.dn21:1.10.13: I also remember that it was the sound of your chariot wheels that pulled me out of that immersion.”
translation_text.dn21:1.11.1: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the gods who were reborn in the host of the thirty-three before me:
translation_text.dn21:1.11.2: ‘When a Realized One arises in the world, perfected and fully awakened, the heavenly hosts swell, while the titan hosts dwindle.’
translation_text.dn21:1.11.3: And I have seen this with my own eyes.
translation_text.dn21:1.11.5: Right here in Kapilavatthu there was a Sakyan lady named Gopikā who had confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and had fulfilled her ethics.
translation_text.dn21:1.11.6: Losing her attachment to femininity, she developed masculinity. When her body broke up, after death, she was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn21:1.11.7: In the company of the gods of the thirty-three she became one of my sons.
translation_text.dn21:1.11.10: Meanwhile three others, mendicants who had led the spiritual life under the Buddha, were reborn in the inferior centaur realm.
translation_text.dn21:1.11.11: There they amused themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, and became my servants and attendants.
translation_text.dn21:1.11.13: ‘Where on earth were you at, good fellows, when you heard the Buddha’s teaching!
translation_text.dn21:1.11.14: For while I was still a woman I had confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and had fulfilled my ethics. I lost my attachment to femininity and developed masculinity. When my body broke up, after death, I was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. In the company of the gods of the thirty-three I became one of Sakka’s sons.
translation_text.dn21:1.11.17: But you, having led the spiritual life under the Buddha, were reborn in the inferior centaur realm.
translation_text.dn21:1.11.18: It is a sad sight indeed to see fellow practitioners reborn in the inferior centaur realm.’
translation_text.dn21:1.11.19: When scolded by Gopaka, two of those gods regained their memory right away. They went to the host of the priests of Divinity, but one god remained attached to sensual pleasures.
translation_text.dn21:1.12.1: ‘“I was a laywoman disciple of the Clear-eyed One,
translation_text.dn21:1.12.3: I was devoted to the Buddha and the teaching,
translation_text.dn21:1.12.4: and I faithfully served the Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn21:1.12.5: Because of the clear rightness of the Buddha’s teaching,
translation_text.dn21:1.12.6: I’m now a mighty, dazzling son of Sakka,
translation_text.dn21:1.12.8: And here they know me as Gopaka.
translation_text.dn21:1.12.9: Then I saw some mendicants who I’d seen before,
translation_text.dn21:1.12.10: dwelling in the host of centaurs.
translation_text.dn21:1.12.12: when I used to be a human.
translation_text.dn21:1.12.13: I served them with food and drink,
translation_text.dn21:1.12.14: and clasped their feet in my own home.
translation_text.dn21:1.12.15: Where on earth were these good fellows at
translation_text.dn21:1.12.16: when they learned the Buddha’s teachings?
translation_text.dn21:1.12.17: For each must know for themselves the teaching
translation_text.dn21:1.12.18: so well-taught, realized by the Clear-eyed One.
translation_text.dn21:1.12.19: I was one who followed you,
translation_text.dn21:1.12.20: having heard the fine words of the noble ones.
translation_text.dn21:1.12.21: I’m now a mighty, dazzling son of Sakka,

translation_text.dn21:2.1.1: Having been granted an opportunity by the Buddha, Sakka asked the first question.
translation_text.dn21:2.1.2: “Good fellow, what fetters bind the gods, humans, titans, dragons, centaurs—and any of the other diverse creatures—
translation_text.dn21:2.1.3: so that, though they wish to be free of enmity, violence, hostility, and hate, they still have enmity, violence, hostility, and hate?”
translation_text.dn21:2.1.4: Such was Sakka’s question to the Buddha.
translation_text.dn21:2.1.6: “Lord of gods, the fetters of jealousy and stinginess bind the gods, humans, titans, dragons, centaurs—and any of the other diverse creatures—
translation_text.dn21:2.1.7: so that, though they wish to be free of enmity, violence, hostility, and hate, they still have enmity, violence, hostility, and hate.”
translation_text.dn21:2.1.8: Such was the Buddha’s answer to Sakka.
translation_text.dn21:2.1.9: Delighted, Sakka approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, saying,
translation_text.dn21:2.1.10: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
translation_text.dn21:2.1.11: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”
translation_text.dn21:2.2.1: And then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, Sakka asked another question:
translation_text.dn21:2.2.2: “But good fellow, what is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of jealousy and stinginess?
translation_text.dn21:2.2.3: When what exists is there jealousy and stinginess?
translation_text.dn21:2.2.4: When what doesn’t exist is there no jealousy and stinginess?”
translation_text.dn21:2.2.5: “The liked and the disliked, lord of gods, are the source of jealousy and stinginess.
translation_text.dn21:2.2.6: When the liked and the disliked exist there is jealousy and stinginess.
translation_text.dn21:2.2.7: When the liked and the disliked don’t exist there is no jealousy and stinginess.”
translation_text.dn21:2.2.8: “But good fellow, what is the source of what is liked and disliked?”
translation_text.dn21:2.2.11: “Desire is the source of what is liked and disliked.”
translation_text.dn21:2.2.14: “But what is the source of desire?”
translation_text.dn21:2.2.20: “But what is the source of thought?”
translation_text.dn21:2.2.23: “Judgments driven by the proliferation of perceptions are the source of thoughts.”
translation_text.dn21:2.3.1: “But how does a mendicant fittingly practice for the cessation of judgments driven by the proliferation of perceptions?”
translation_text.dn21:2.3.3: “Lord of gods, there are two kinds of happiness, I say:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.4: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.5: There are two kinds of sadness, I say:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.6: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.7: There are two kinds of equanimity, I say:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.8: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.9: Why did I say that there are two kinds of happiness?
translation_text.dn21:2.3.10: Well, should you know of a happiness:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.11: ‘When I cultivate this kind of happiness, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not cultivate that kind of happiness.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.12: Whereas, should you know of a happiness:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.13: ‘When I cultivate this kind of happiness, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should cultivate that kind of happiness.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.14: And that which is free of placing the mind and keeping it connected is better than that which still involves placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.15: That’s why I said there are two kinds of happiness.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.17: Why did I say that there are two kinds of sadness?
translation_text.dn21:2.3.18: Well, should you know of a sadness:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.19: ‘When I cultivate this kind of sadness, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not cultivate that kind of sadness.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.20: Whereas, should you know of a sadness:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.21: ‘When I cultivate this kind of sadness, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should cultivate that kind of sadness.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.22: And that which is free of placing the mind and keeping it connected is better than that which still involves placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.23: That’s why I said there are two kinds of sadness.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.25: Why did I say that there are two kinds of equanimity?
translation_text.dn21:2.3.26: Well, should you know of an equanimity:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.27: ‘When I cultivate this kind of equanimity, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not cultivate that kind of equanimity.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.28: Whereas, should you know of an equanimity:
translation_text.dn21:2.3.29: ‘When I cultivate this kind of equanimity, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should cultivate that kind of equanimity.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.30: And that which is free of placing the mind and keeping it connected is better than that which still involves placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.31: That’s why I said there are two kinds of equanimity.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.33: That’s how a mendicant fittingly practices for the cessation of judgments driven by the proliferation of perceptions.”
translation_text.dn21:2.3.34: Such was the Buddha’s answer to Sakka.
translation_text.dn21:2.3.35: Delighted, Sakka approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, saying,
translation_text.dn21:2.3.36: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
translation_text.dn21:2.3.37: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”
translation_text.dn21:2.4.1: And then Sakka asked another question:
translation_text.dn21:2.4.2: “But good fellow, how does a mendicant practice for restraint in the monastic code?”
translation_text.dn21:2.4.3: “Lord of gods, I say that there are two kinds of bodily behavior:
translation_text.dn21:2.4.4: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.5: I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior:
translation_text.dn21:2.4.6: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.7: There are two kinds of search, I say:
translation_text.dn21:2.4.8: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.9: Why did I say that there are two kinds of bodily behavior?
translation_text.dn21:2.4.10: Well, should you know of a bodily conduct:
translation_text.dn21:2.4.11: ‘When I cultivate this kind of bodily conduct, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not cultivate that kind of bodily conduct.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.12: Whereas, should you know of a bodily conduct:
translation_text.dn21:2.4.13: ‘When I cultivate this kind of bodily conduct, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should cultivate that kind of bodily conduct.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.14: That’s why I said there are two kinds of bodily behavior.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.17: Why did I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior?
translation_text.dn21:2.4.19: Well, should you know of a kind of verbal behavior that it causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline, you should not cultivate it.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.20: Whereas, should you know of a kind of verbal behavior that it causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow, you should cultivate it.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.21: That’s why I said there are two kinds of verbal behavior.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.24: Why did I say that there are two kinds of search?
translation_text.dn21:2.4.26: Well, should you know of a kind of search that it causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline, you should not cultivate it.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.27: Whereas, should you know of a kind of search that it causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow, you should cultivate it.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.28: That’s why I said there are two kinds of search.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.31: That’s how a mendicant practices for restraint in the monastic code.”
translation_text.dn21:2.4.32: Such was the Buddha’s answer to Sakka.
translation_text.dn21:2.4.33: Delighted, Sakka approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, saying,
translation_text.dn21:2.4.34: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
translation_text.dn21:2.4.35: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”
translation_text.dn21:2.5.1: And then Sakka asked another question:
translation_text.dn21:2.5.2: “But good fellow, how does a mendicant practice for restraint of the sense faculties?”
translation_text.dn21:2.5.3: “Lord of gods, I say that there are two kinds of sight known by the eye:
translation_text.dn21:2.5.4: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.dn21:2.5.5: There are two kinds of sound known by the ear …
translation_text.dn21:2.5.14: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.”
translation_text.dn21:2.5.15: When the Buddha said this, Sakka said to him:
translation_text.dn21:2.5.16: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement:
translation_text.dn21:2.5.17: You should not cultivate the kind of sight known by the eye which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.dn21:2.5.18: And you should cultivate the kind of sight known by the eye which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.dn21:2.5.19: You should not cultivate the kind of sound,
translation_text.dn21:2.5.23: or idea known by the mind which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.dn21:2.5.24: And you should cultivate the kind of idea known by the mind which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.dn21:2.5.25: Sir, that’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.
translation_text.dn21:2.5.26: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”
translation_text.dn21:2.6.1: And then Sakka asked another question:
translation_text.dn21:2.6.2: “Good fellow, do all ascetics and brahmins have a single doctrine, ethics, desire, and attachment?”
translation_text.dn21:2.6.3: “No, lord of gods, they do not.”
translation_text.dn21:2.6.5: “The world has many and diverse elements.
translation_text.dn21:2.6.6: Whatever element sentient beings insist on in this world of many and diverse elements, they obstinately stick to it, insisting that:
translation_text.dn21:2.6.7: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.dn21:2.6.8: That’s why not all ascetics and brahmins have a single doctrine, ethics, desire, and attachment.”
translation_text.dn21:2.6.9: “Good fellow, have all ascetics and brahmins reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal?”
translation_text.dn21:2.6.10: “No, lord of gods, they have not.”
translation_text.dn21:2.6.12: “Those mendicants who are freed through the ending of craving have reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal.
translation_text.dn21:2.6.13: That’s why not all ascetics and brahmins have reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal.”
translation_text.dn21:2.6.14: Such was the Buddha’s answer to Sakka.
translation_text.dn21:2.6.15: Delighted, Sakka approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, saying,
translation_text.dn21:2.6.16: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
translation_text.dn21:2.6.17: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”
translation_text.dn21:2.6.18: And then Sakka, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, said to him,
translation_text.dn21:2.7.1: “Turbulence, sir, is a disease, a boil, a dart. Turbulence drags a person to be regenerated in one state of existence or another.
translation_text.dn21:2.7.2: That’s why a person finds themselves in states high and low.
translation_text.dn21:2.7.3: Elsewhere, among other ascetics and brahmins, I wasn’t even given a chance to ask these questions that the Buddha has answered.
translation_text.dn21:2.7.4: The dart of doubt and indecision has lain within me for a long time, but the Buddha has plucked it out.”
translation_text.dn21:2.7.5: “Lord of gods, do you recall having asked this question of other ascetics and brahmins?”
translation_text.dn21:2.7.7: “If you wouldn’t mind, lord of gods, tell me how they answered.”
translation_text.dn21:2.7.8: “It’s no trouble when someone such as the Blessed One is sitting here.”
translation_text.dn21:2.7.10: “Sir, I approached those who I imagined were ascetics and brahmins living in the wilderness, in remote lodgings. But they were stumped by my question, and they even questioned me in return:
translation_text.dn21:2.7.13: ‘Good fellow, I am Sakka, lord of gods.’
translation_text.dn21:2.7.14: So they asked me another question:
translation_text.dn21:2.7.15: ‘But lord of gods, what deed brought you to this position?’
translation_text.dn21:2.7.16: So I taught them the Dhamma as I had learned and memorized it.
translation_text.dn21:2.7.17: And they were pleased with just that much:
translation_text.dn21:2.7.18: ‘We have seen Sakka, lord of gods! And he answered our questions!’
translation_text.dn21:2.7.19: Invariably, they become my disciples, I don’t become theirs.
translation_text.dn21:2.7.20: But sir, I am the Buddha’s disciple, a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”
translation_text.dn21:2.7.22: “Lord of gods, do you recall ever feeling such joy and happiness before?”
translation_text.dn21:2.7.25: “Once upon a time, sir, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.
translation_text.dn21:2.7.26: In that battle the gods won and the titans lost.
translation_text.dn21:2.7.27: It occurred to me as victor,
translation_text.dn21:2.7.28: ‘Now the gods shall enjoy both the nectar of the gods and the nectar of the titans.’
translation_text.dn21:2.7.29: But sir, that joy and happiness is in the sphere of the rod and the sword. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn21:2.7.30: But the joy and happiness I feel listening to the Buddha’s teaching is not in the sphere of the rod and the sword. It does lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”
translation_text.dn21:2.8.1: “But lord of gods, what reason do you see for speaking of such joy and happiness?”
translation_text.dn21:2.8.2: “I see six reasons to speak of such joy and happiness, sir.

translation_text.dn21:2.10.1: Then Sakka addressed the centaur Pañcasikha,
translation_text.dn21:2.10.2: “Dear Pañcasikha, you were very helpful to me, since you first charmed the Buddha,
translation_text.dn21:2.10.3: after which I went to see him.
translation_text.dn21:2.10.4: I shall appoint you to your father’s position—you shall be king of the centaurs. And I give you Bhaddā Suriyavaccasā, for she loves you very much.”
translation_text.dn21:2.10.5: Then Sakka, touching the ground with his hand, expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
translation_text.dn21:2.10.6: “Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.dn21:2.10.7: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.dn21:2.10.8: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”
translation_text.dn21:2.10.9: And while this discourse was being spoken, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in Sakka, lord of gods:
translation_text.dn21:2.10.10: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
translation_text.dn21:2.10.12: Such were the questions Sakka was invited to ask, and which were answered by the Buddha.
translation_text.dn21:2.10.13: And that’s why the name of this discussion is “Sakka’s Questions”.
